title: Frank Gehry and Gordan Ramsey to star in new film about Battersea Power Station transformation
author: Niall Patrick Walsh

text: anchor Image credit: Ruben J Davies / Wikimedia, licensed under CC BY-SA 4.0 Independent UK production company Chief has completed The Masterplan, a new documentary exploring the architectural and cultural transformation of Battersea Power Station in London. After decades of disuse, areas of the station were repurposed by WilkinsonEyre for housing and retail through a £9 billion ($12.2 billion USD) overhaul completed in 2022, with Foster + Partners designing a new Apple Store for the station in 2023. Directed by Chief’s Nate Camponi and commissioned by Stripe Communications and the Battersea Power Station Development Group, the new film presents an in-depth account of the power station’s history, from its origins as an industrial landmark to its revival as a mixed-use cultural destination. The film uses a combination of historical narrative, visual storytelling, and personal reflections to document the complex process of redeveloping the site and its evolving relationship with the city. Jason Flemyng as The Raconteur in The Masterplan. Image courtesy: ChiefActor Jason Flemyng (Lock, Stock & Two Smoking Barrels, Boiling Point) stars as The Raconteur, a fictional “Battersea lifer” who guides viewers through the power station’s layered history. The film also features contributions from high-profile figures with personal and professional ties to London’s cultural scene, including chef Gordon Ramsay, DJ Fat Tony, Frank Gehry, and architectural historian Marcus Binney. An original score composed by Max Perryment accompanies the film.

    Independent UK production company Chief has completed The Masterplan, a new documentary exploring the architectural and cultural transformation of Battersea Power Station in London. After decades of disuse, areas of the station were repurposed by WilkinsonEyre for housing and retail through a £9 billion ($12.2 billion USD) overhaul completed in 2022, with Foster + Partners designing a new Apple Store for the station in 2023.

    Directed by Chief’s Nate Camponi and commissioned by Stripe Communications and the Battersea Power Station Development Group, the new film presents an in-depth account of the power station’s history, from its origins as an industrial landmark to its revival as a mixed-use cultural destination. The film uses a combination of historical narrative, visual storytelling, and personal reflections to document the complex process of redeveloping the site and its evolving relationship with the city.

    Actor Jason Flemyng (Lock, Stock & Two Smoking Barrels, Boiling Point) stars as The Raconteur, a fictional “Battersea lifer” who guides viewers through the power station’s layered history. The film also features contributions from high-profile figures with personal and professional ties to London’s cultural scene, including chef Gordon Ramsay, DJ Fat Tony, Frank Gehry, and architectural historian Marcus Binney. An original score composed by Max Perryment accompanies the film.
